content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
It's a good problem, description is clear.

I just think you should fix the typo on the first test case from EXEMPLE to EXAMPLE

This could also be a great addition to the "shortest" mode.
just did 113 chars in JS, feel free to let me know if you have a better solution  ; )

r=readline
d=r(l=r(s=r())).split` `
print([...s].map((k,i)=>String.fromCharCode(k.charCodeAt()+ +d[i%l])).join``)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: That's really cool !

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: i like the idea

Goal section
* For Fastest Mode, you need to include much more explanation than "play with alphabet".

Input section
* Please state the variable types for Line 2 and LIne 3.
* Please state that the integers are space-separated for Line 3.

Constraints section
* Don't write anything if there is no constraint.

Cases
* Including quotation marks in the first input line means some coding time has to be spent on "data cleansing", which seems unncessary. I think the focus should be placed on the decoding process instead.

Thanks.
Great, thanks for the feedback! I will apply these tips to the code tomorrow

Thank you.

Please note that "Exemple" should be spelled as "Example".

Also would you please explain the array of integers in the Goal section? Do you mean Caesar shift should be performed based on every integer in that array, one by one?
Thanks for the comment, I misunderstood the second part of the comment, are the instructions better explained this way ?

That's not an explanation. That's just an example, which is very useful actually, but still not enough.

I would suggest to add a few points e.g.
• The given array of integers represents the shift(s) that have been applied to the original string.
• Apply the 1st shift to the first character, the 2nd shift to the second character, etc.
• Cycle through the array of shifts repeatedly. That is, when the end of the array is reached, go back to the beginning.
• If a shift is <<positive>>, <<encoding>> a character with that shift means moving <<forward>> in the alphabet. <<Negative>> means moving <<backward>>.
• Your job is to <<decode>>. That means the direction will be reverse of the above.
• Only the 26 alphabet letters are considered. If you reach the beginning/end of the alphabet while shifting, wrap around and go to the other end to continue.

*****

Other comments
* As I said before, please remove the quotation marks in the input string as they mean extra parsing.
* I think it may be a bit difficult for Reverse mode. I'd suggest to remove it, but it's up to you. Also let's see other moderators' opinions.

Thank you.
Thanks, I have a long way to go before I have this type of exercise creation analysis, it's very interesting!
